I wanted to love this series, I really did. The first 2 episodes were amazing, I honestly thought I had a masterpiece in my hands but as the show progresses I am proven pretty wrong. The story was brilliantly intriguing, the characters interactions rivetting, but sadly that's the only thing that has kept me from dropping the show this far. The plot alone is flawless in my opinion and the premise pretty unique, though it is a bit strangely paced at some points that's forgivable.
Generally, my biggest pet peeve with it is the slow but sure decrease in the quality of the art, I meanit happens with most anime as they progress but with Banana Fish, it was extremely noticeable, like to the point where in some frames the characters don't even look like themselves and it bothers me to no end. The first few episodes were really well animated and I have to admit the unique look was one of the things that got me into it in the first place but its so sad to see what it has become at this point.


Another pet peeve was the soundtrack, I want to like it but in most scenes, it just ends up making me cringe. It just comes off as cheesy or overdone. I mean the scenes are meant to be dramatic or heart wrenching but they just end up falling flat as the soundtrack can't carry particular scenes or they are just really poorly framed.


The characters are Banana Fish's saving grace. Honestly, they are pretty well constructed and as the audience, you really end up emotionally invested in what they are going through. All in all, the show is worth watching purely for the story and characters and I still do recommend that everyone interested watch this show. It might not be a masterpiece but its definitely quite original.

We are only 6 episodes in but so far it has stuck fairly close to the source material (which I recommend btw). If I had one complaint about that it is that they had changed all the character's most iconic outfit looks.
The characters in the show are fun. Ash, who has had terrible things happen to him, still manages to smile and have fun with his friends. Eiji, who knows nothing about the life of crime that he is thrust into, is starting to show us more complex sides to him. Shorter, as expected, is amazing. And, though bald Shorter will be remembered, I likethat they let him keep his hair. 


The plot is speed up quite a bit in order to fit it into only 24 episodes but they seem to be hitting the main plot lines fairly well. (If you want to see more cutesy bonding and joking around, read the manga! :) ). I am excited to see how the anime further progresses, especially once some more characters are introduced.


I will say, if you are here looking for the next yoi or for gay romance 'uwu' this isnt the anime for it. The relationship between Ash and Eiji is full of love and I do believe they are soulmates, but with all the trauma that Ash has experienced, you just aren't going to get that here. (unless the anime goes WAY off book. at which point i may have to change my review).

I will not forgive anyone who gives this anything less than a 10.
Best anime I have ever seen, and I have watched a lot of anime.
Many themes of the different worlds presented by a Japanese traveler experiencing America. A story on friendship, loss, acceptance, and most of all struggle.
Great story line, character development, twists, all around amazing.
I don't want to say anything else as this series has an amazing ending I will not be forgetting soon and I do not want to spoil it under any means.
I will definitely be reading the manga to enjoy this anime completely, and I have never read manga beforein my life.\n
If you have any respect as a weeb or as simply an anime watcher, please watch this anime and give it the respect that it deserves.

Honestly when I first heard of this show, I thought it would be boring, just a confusing anime about drugs and mafias. While that IS the case somehow with every new episode I get more and more excited.
Story: 9
Although I am not a fan of stories about drugs, pedophilia, etc. Banana Fish does an excellent job at telling it's story with the characters, or at least that's my opinion. While the show handles such topics it shows how characters care for each other, not always in a romantic way. By friendship, by family, etc.
Is the story Original? Well I'm sure there are plenty of notjust anime but any story in general that handles these topics but again the characters seem to be the reason for this anime's success in storytelling.



Art: 9


Art styles like Ouran Highschool, Is the order a rabbit? and Blend S makes it look like all characters you meet are from the same country (Or are of the same race). In Ouran there have been quite a few characters who aren't or aren't fully Japanese although it's art style suggest they are all of the same race.


However Banana fish's style makes it clear for it's viewers to tell what race they are, Black, White or Asian, And this anime does not have what people call 'Same face syndrome'. Another anime I could say has a similar way of showing one's race through art style is Yuri on Ice, whether the character is Russian, Japanese, Canadian, from Thailand, etc.



Sound: 10


I myself is a person who would watch Dubs if it were available, the fact that Banana fish didn't had a Dub was one of the reasons I hesitated to watch it.   

However when I first heard the voice acting in the first episode, All I could say is it's pretty good.


The voices really fits what kind of character they are, other background sound effects are good as well, The OP is very catchy and relates to one of our main characters, Ash lynx.



Character: 10


For me, the story is almost nothing original, there are plenty of stories not just in anime but in general where it would handle such topics, However with these characters for me is what really made this anime stand.

To me my favorite was Eiji, (Don't worry these won't be spoilers ahead)

throughout the story (so far) Eiji is shown to be an inexperienced person (Compared to Ash who has experienced rape, killing people and Drinking, which is something people his age wouldn't normally experience) but throughout the situations he encounters he is a very kind person willing to be by ash's side as much as possible.


You might be thinking "Oh GREAT! This person's just a Fujoshi!" actually I am not, in fact I really hate shounen-ai and shojo-ai (As someone who is Biromantic) However this anime shows the two characters caring and being by each other's side. It's not all sex.



Enjoyment: 10


Each episode is always exciting, discovering what would happen to the characters and what new amazing and heartfelt things would happen, there was loss and wins and it's very enjoyable (again) especially with the very likeable characters you meet.



Overall: 9


It has it's flaws but also it's Good sides and I think it was the Good ones that sticked out to me the most. not a perfect 10? Well again I'm not a Big fan of stories with such topics but Banana fish was able to make this series very enjoyable.

I haven’t cried actual tears over fictional characters in a while but damn. I’m a mess.
I was a little hesitant to start Banana Fish, mostly because I couldn’t quite figure out wtf it was about. My gods, do not let anything weird, the age of the source, or anything deter you from watching/ reading this beautiful beast. My friend got me hooked on the anime, and I plowed through the manga once episode 19 of the anime got released because I’m impatient and can’t wait. I’m so glad I did, I have even more appreciation for all the work that went into the anime. Butbe warned, it is in a tragedy category for a reason. So many tears. 


this is kinda long and spoilery ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Eiji Okumura is an innocent cinnamon roll fresh from Japan. After an injury ruined his pole vaulting career, he finds himself lost and unsure of what to do with his life. Ibe takes him under his wing and enlists him as his assistant in America where he is reporting on street gangs.


Ash Lynx is on the polar opposite of the innocence spectrum. The 17-year-old is the leader of a thriving gang in Manhattan and has been through hell and back. After his brother left for the army, Ash ran away and was kidnapped by Dino Golzine, the head of a child prostitution ring. Under Golzine’s “care” Ash was trained to be his personal pet, where he learned how to please customers, behave as a member of high society, as well as fight and wield firearms. 


Ash instantly takes a liking to Eiji during an interview with Ibe. Their bond deepens when they are captured by a rival gang and Eiji sacrifices himself in order to save the others. They end up working together to uncover the mystery of Banana Fish, a new synthetic drug, while dealing with the struggles of rival gangs and Golzine. 


The differences from anime to manga were minimal, mostly slight appearance changes. Ash is a little more soft and fluffy in the anime, and Shorter never shaves his mohawk. There’s a lot of backstory missing or displaced, which I’m assuming was just due to time constraints that always exist with anime. They tried so so hard to make scene match the art in the manga, I appreciate that aspect so much. They were very detailed in sticking to the source materials. Even with them modernizing it a little, the biggest change is that they all have cell phones and it doesn’t really make a difference to the story.  


This is really the best addition to the shounen-ai genre. Ash and Eiji just love each other for a multitude of reasons, and it’s nothing sexual. They just compliment each other, and fit together like puzzle pieces, like the Jian bird from Chinese mythology that has one wing and one eye and must fly in pairs to make a whole. There’s nothing creepy or forced about Ash and Eiji, they just care about each other and want to see each other happy. It’s just so wholesome.


I love all of the characters. The side ones are fleshed out, they have a story that matters as well. You really get to know each and every one of them (at least in the manga, the anime has some time constraints :c but it still counts ok.)


And oh the end… the end fits so perfectly. It makes me horribly sad and I really wish Ash could have found long term happiness. He was granted little blips once Eiji came into his life… but we never got to see him completely happy and at ease. His whole life was pain, and I just so wanted to see him happy and safe and in Japan with Eiji forever. He’s so loveable and just a damaged baby and I want the world for him. But his death makes sense in this setting. It’s realistic and really just completes the series in a way. I was definitely more emotional about the manga but I always am with reading. The animation would beautiful and they kept it true to the manga and oof my lil heart hurts all over again.

I knew this series only by her name, thanks to an artist. When i heard about the anime, i read the plot and i found it intriguing. Now, i can say i love Banana Fish. The anime sets the story after more than 30 years than the original manga, but nothing is lost. Ash, Shorter, Eiji, they are the same. I have to read the manga though.
This story is so good and it's almost scaring that now, in 2018, this story could be so real only changing his original setting. 
I wish this series would more success, it deserves it.
I will cry, i will panick,but i would never regret having watched it.

It was July this year when I kept seeing people fangirl over the first few episodes of Banana Fish in my Twitter TL. I've heard of its manga 11 years ago when it was mentioned in this one book that I read (I forget the title) as one of the best mangas of all time. But I ignored it because it simply didn't pique my interest at that time. I was going to pass the show up too like I did the manga, but a screenshot of Ash’s and Eiji’s ‘scene’ in the prison successfully served as bait for my rotten fujoshi mind and mademe make a self-reminder to watch the show sometime later. I did so 3 months later with an expectation for a show that’s full of fujo-bait, stereotypical fangirl-material characters, and shallow plot.


But never have I felt so happy for being so wrong.


[Story: 9]


What I like the most about Banana Fish's story is that it's consistent from the very start to its final moment. It always feels like everything is at stake. Viewers were kept on the edge of the seat every time, so we can feel a palpable tension of wanting to know what’s going to happen next because nothing is certain. In such a way, this is a show that's very proper to be binged because the plot is moving very seamlessly from one episode to the next. Every Easter eggs come back around the way (in my opinion) FMAB does.


You may partially argue that some of the crimes or plots were orchestrated far too dramatically, but in actuality... they don't. Banana Fish's world is as fucked up as the world we're living right now. Illegal human trials for medical and military purposes, money-laundering, VIP child sex ring (check out Jonathan King and stan Twitter's latest outburst: #SimonCowellOverParty), street and gang fights over territories/hierarchy/revenge, etc. All of that and how they cleverly use the setting (my favorite is the inter-state travels and the show’s explicit use of NY city design) actually make the show feels very real and believable.


Most of the key information used was pretty spot on too. I’m a pharmacy student & /almost/ everything about the drug discovery process in the show are pretty accurate (well, except the VERY hard-to-believe pharmacological action of the drug itself. Like, sure it can let you hallucinate, but I don't think one will become a puppet that can be controlled via exclusive command).


Aside from that one topic, there are actually two more (spoilery) pet peeves that made me take a point off of the story:


1. It seems that the story goes on for at least 3 months. So I don’t get how Eiji & Ibe can stay that long without renewing their visa. Did they apply for a journalist/media visa for that long? And if Eiji got arrested during that time, won’t that make his return to Japan difficult even after someone bailed him out? This protocol issue might be a minor ordeal but it's something that always creeps up in the back of my mind when I'm watching the show.

2. It’s VERY weird how Ash can always bait people with the promise of sex. Like, I know his character design is supposed to make that possible for him but I don't think a professional doctor or security (whose job is to goddamn secure their captives) fall for that OBVIOUS trap.


[Characters: 10]


Banana Fish is a show that despite features a rather diverse (all age, all race, all facial/body features, all kinds of personalities) and large cast, didn't fail to make each of the characters stands out in their own way. They were all complex, felt real, and human-like. Everybody (no matter how big/small their part is) had their own agenda that happens to overlap with each others’ and affects the course of the story in the long-run.


I wanted to diss the two main antagonists (Dino and Foxx) as stereotypical evil characters, but when I thought of it again, even they who served as nothing but the ultimate evil scheme executioners, seemed real because hedonistic, power-hungry bastards like them exist in real life too. And it’s no surprise that people like these often take the reign in politics and business.


Our main duo, Ash and Eiji, were not a problem for me too. Ash was very complex and fleshed out. He seemed slightly overpowered at times, but it’s clear that he’s not flawless. Eiji, on the other hand, almost made me took off a point for ‘characters’ for being too simple and vessel-like. I almost criticized him for being a mere ‘friend of Ash’ instead of a character of his own. However, I tried to recall earlier episodes and remembered that what geared him in the first place was actually not solely for Ash’s sake. Eiji is a Japanese young-adult who have always been sheltered in the comfort of his small hometown. So when he was injured, robbed of a chance to delve into a sport that he’s interested in, and was introduced for the first time to this exciting and dangerous world he had never experienced before, his actions became /his/. And when he grew closer to Ash, /that/ is when I can accept that he did things for Ash’s sake too.


As for their relationship, I wouldn’t deny the presence of homosexual undertones between the two. But it’s pretty hard to convince yourself so because there were plenty of homophobic undertones woven in the show as well (most of them were related to how the characters portray being gay = disgusting). So, really, just interpret Ash & Eiji’s relationship just like how you treat Yuri & Victor’s: whichever suits your narrative and with a grain of salt. All I know is that I share Ash’s feelings of comfort & relief whenever I see the two just laying low in each other’s company and being safe in general (yea, I’m talking about those domestic scenes). They were probably the only times during the whole course of the story where I felt that temporary ‘everything is gonna be alright’ moment and wasn’t in the edge of my seat.


[Animation & Art: 9]


I personally think that the studio did a lot of great stylistic decisions for a 1985 manga adaptation. Instead of blatantly copy-pasteing the art style just for the sake of preservation (I’m winking at you, Sailor Moon Crystal), they only adapted the major lineart of the characters and ‘modernizing’ it from there. As a result, you get a modern quality show off a 1985 work that’s still able to retain the retro feel thanks to the character designs, fashion styles, and the way the setting was drawn.


More specifically about character designs, they’re +++++. Everyone’s distinct without trying to make them caricature-like. Even minor characters have special features that differentiate each other and it’s apparent that the staffs put extra attention to every characters’ details.


Overall, no critique for the art/animation in general. But since nothing is really ‘ground-breaking’, I won’t give it a 10.


[Sound: 9]


This is the second time ever (MDZS was the first) that I noticed the uniqueness of SFXs & OSTs in an anime (granted, I need to watch even more anime first but this is still an anomaly). The OSTs were very thematic. Some action/dodgy parts sounded cool & retro and some more emotional parts were backed with a classical piece that wasn’t overly dramatic. They were also carefully and cleverly placed. I noticed during some emotional scenes, the OST was purposefully removed and they actually made the scene more powerful because they felt real instead of romanticized.


Another event of careful placement was during the scene where Eiji teaches ‘sayonara’ to Ash. The ending song slowly bled through the scene and the lyrics were heard clearly: ‘Would I still have the chance for us to say goodbye?’ and I think the timing was just pure brilliance. The overall lyrics in all the OP & ED actually suit Ash’s feelings and emotions so well. I don’t know if they were written like that on purpose or not, but I really appreciate it.


[Overall Enjoyment: 10]


I initially watched Banana Fish for its fanservice, but I stayed for everything else because simply reducing this show to a material to fangirl to is a huge disservice. Even if I meant to treat it like such, I wouldn’t be able to do it because the plot and characters would just suck me in and made me forgot to fangirl anyway.


Without spoiling anything, I think the ending (I’m talking about the general ending here, not focusing on what happened with one/two characters only) didn’t come off pretentiously edgy; or at least it didn’t feel like it. Even if it does though, the ending was written & directed very beautifully to the point that we felt as if everything happened very naturally. It didn’t run away from what the whole show was built upon, but it also encompasses the little positive things that gear all the characters forward throughout the show: love and freedom.


I finished the whole thing feeling overwhelmed and full (and yeah I did shed some tears).


[Average Score]


47/5 = 9.4

Rounded to 9

SPOILER----
I have never felt so anxious waiting for an episode, ever. After episode 22, I knew it was all about to end and it was getting more and more sad by the minute. Watching a character evolving the way Eiji and Ash did, and watching their relationship grow in a world with such savage environments, I grew to love those two, so much. Every moment they had together made me feel all warm and fuzzy. I admit, I didn't watch the anime from the first episode, but from after episode 7 had just been aired. I saw a thumbnail on youtube with the scene ofAsh kissing Eiji, that made me want to try watching the anime in the first place.


I was very very sceptical thinking "Man I don't like the art, it's so different from the anime art I know" but I quickly learned to accept that, and in time, I started to love the art.


It was realistic in the way that the characters eyes were more or less, a normal size, which I don't see often in anime these days.


Getting to know each character and their names wasn't as confusing as I thought it would be, Ash and Eiji were unique names that I never knew of, back then. The way I was able to recognise Ash's name was each time a character in the anime said his name. "Asshu" which each time reminded me of "achoo" as in a sneeze. That fact, made me say "bless you" out loud, each time someone said Ash's name.


After Ash's fight with Arthur, he was brought to the hospital. After that episode I was just so curious about what would happen next, and so, I read the manga. And I'm stating that I'm not a good reader but it seems like a manga with pictures and short texts, made things easier for me. I was getting more and more into the manga so I continued. Suddenly, I was watching Eiji and Ibe leaving N.Y again, and Ash was reading the letter from Eiji. When I saw that Ash let his guard down I was thinking "Ah he's been stabbed dozens of times, he'll get it fixed" But did he though? Did he actually get it fixed? Why didn't he?


From that moment I prayed that the anime wouldn't turn out like the manga did because that would be even more painful, watching the character I love, sitting there with blood and tears all over the letter.


As the anime continued, I was quickly learning that "Oh wow.. They're going for the manga.." due to how precise and familiar each scene was. But that didn't stop me from looking forward to each episode, I couldn't wait, each day was so long but the episode, so short. It felt like I was getting so obsessed with the anime that nothing else really mattered but getting through the week to watch the next episode. That was nothing new for me, getting obsessed with something and wanting to praise it like I would God until it's over.


Although, after episode 22, I didn't look forward to the next episodes no more, I knew what was coming. I knew I was gonna bawl, I knew I'd need buckets for my tears. I've fallen completely in love with Ash and his beautiful person. And fallen even more in love with his relationship with Eiji, each bromance moment got me all excited and it was such a nice feeling.


That relationship is the most beautiful thing I've seen, ever. I didn't know that an anime could be this touching to someone like me. And especially when I think about how sceptical I was when watching the first episodes of the anime.


Ash fascinated me on so many points. A beautiful young man with the mind of a supercomputer, fangs and claws as sharp as a knife, and at first, a cold blooded killer who showed no emotion nor remorse.


Eiji, the other main character, just about a young year older than Ash, is a peaceful and observant person, whose aura could affect even the most cold blooded killer. That peaceful and carefree, cheerful and always smiling person, affected Ash in so many ways. That's so beautiful. I can't describe it any better than 'beautiful'.


At first, I really disliked the villains, especially Yut, for kidnapping Eiji like he did, and forcing Shorter to do the work of betraying Ash. But the worst thing was when he ordered some of Sing's gang members to attack Ash and Eiji when they were alone together. Yut knew that Ash wasn't on guard when he was with Eiji and therefore stated that it was the perfect chance to attack. I started asking myself "Is Yut really a villain?" His reason for going after Eiji was because Ash found love, despite having such a brutal upgrowing like Yut himself did. Although, Yut remained alone. Blanca stated that he had to learn how to love others, in order to be loved. I believe that's true. At first I even thought of Blanca as a villain but that quickly changed, due to his soft spot when it comes to Ash.


Without a second thought, Eiji took the bullet instead of Ash. Literally. As Eiji was just laying there, bleeding heavily, his only thoughts were "Is Ash okay?"


To think that those two would, without a second thought, give away their everything for each other in a heartbeat. What could possibly make a relationship more pure and beautiful than this?


Ash deep down knew how it was gonna turn out in the end, but needed someone by his side as "mental backup" as I call it, in order to keep on moving forward.


For the first time, Ash felt warmth. He had the feeling of being loved. The feeling of not being indebted. It never stroke Eiji that he would need Ash to do something in return if Eiji did Ash a favour.


This anime made me realise that the story isn't far from the world we live in. The world is savage, brutal but beautiful. Watching the anime as it was being aired has been one of my happiest moments. Watching a relationship like Ash and Eiji's, really just impressed me in every single way, and I don't get easily impressed. I have watched a LOT of anime over the years and I knew as this anime was airing, it was taking the place on my top 3 favourite anime list.


I don't think I'll ever be able to cope with how things turned out in the last episode, never have I ever felt such an ache in the chest from an anime. No, not just an anime, overall, series, movies. In the manga, Ash died. But did he really die in the anime? I don't know anymore. I was sure that he did but after being told that this might not have been the case, I feel a bit better. I needed to get all this out, while typing this, I was bawling. I can't get over this heartbreaking story.


Some people say that Ash gave up because he finally found love. But I'm just thinking.. Isn't that one more reason to live? Living for the one he loves?


Eiji's impact on Ash impressed me by a ton. It's so amazing, watching these two guys changing with each episode.


I'm glad the side novels didn't take part in these 24 episodes, as they state that Ash is dead. So I still feel like there's hope somewhere.


Anyway I just needed to get this out.


Watching this anime was one of the most amazing journeys I've ever been on. Thank you for creating such a painful, yet beautiful masterpiece.

There are always some tv series, movies, cartoon, anime that people can say that they are not your typical stuff. That these are truly exceptional from what we have been getting in the past. That this is something unique and nothing else is like it.
Banana Fish easily falls into that category of anime that anyone can say that there is nothing like it.
Like Berserk, Samurai Champloo, Cowboy Bebop, this series has its own style and uniqueness that no other anime has.
The story is beautifully developed with a great theme.
The background tracks are distinctively attractive which makes you get involved with the anime.

I've never written an anime review, not even considered it - but for Banana Fish, I just have to. I have never even binge watched something so quick but uhh here we are, 20 episodes seen and craving for more. I'm recommending everyone to do the same - to drop the prejudices like "thE NaMe iS WEirD iS this fOR kiDs???oR about cooking?? eating???hm" and just welcome the pain! ! :･ﾟ☆✧
My English and especially the lack of adjectives would make a longer review awkward, so I'm saying it quickly and once only so uhhh listen,, watch this anime.
The best part, also known as the plot,is thrilling and makes you want to see more. The characters are wonderfully written (things that happen to them make you feel things too! wow!) And I'm living for the differences between the main characters, Ash and Eiji. Beeeeautiful.\n\n
Bonus points for the music! I often skip openings and endings but I don't think I did it even once with Banana Fish? The songs are just,, really my taste. Best of the year - at least. Voice acting is also on point, especially Ash's VA is really fitting for him in my opinion!\n\n
Art is very pleasing. It has a recognizable 80's vibe which I love. And Ash's outfits thoo!

Amazing! That's a good word to sum up Banana Fish. At first glance, I was a little afraid to watch the anime, mainly because I have read many comments saying that it was a completely "gay" anime. However, after watching the first 3 episodes, I’ve realized that this is an unfair comment and is by the way very prejudiced.
If you are a person who in hypothesis none admits the "homosexual" topic in an anime, Banana Fish is not for you. However, let's be clear: this is not the focus of the anime, much less the main theme.
I was struck by the primacy that such heavyand profound themes are treated. At some point, I did not know if I should cry together with Ash, or should be angry with the situation. This anime really messed with my feelings and with my psychological. In fact, it is a rather heavy anime psychological. 


One of the strengths for me is the soundtrack. The opening song is amazing; this music is very good, of those that stay all day in the mind. I really loved it! The art goes back to the 80's, when the manga was written. At first the design may seem strange but considered the time, it fit very well in context. In addition, depicting the city of NY in small details such as graffiti on walls, buildings, stairs, alleys and bars in basements, makes you feel very much inside the atmosphere of the city in the 80's.


Another good point is how the anime really demonstrates the humanity of the characters. They are not mere anime characters. For me, few animes had this ability to express what the characters are feeling, causing in us empathy, getting very close to reality, manly in moments of suffering. I suffered a lot along with the characters!


It's worth watching. I'm already sad because it’s close to the end. 

I piece of advice: don’t be led by negative comments! Just like I did, just watch the anime and draw your own conclusions!

Probably best anime of the year. Beyond the shounen-ai tag, the series itself is so good that anyone could enjoy it, it has a great and intricate plot and immerses you with the characters, their thoughts and feelings. The music is as well just great and fits the pace just perfectly. Although being an adaptation of a somewhat not so recent manga, they've managed to blend our modern times just fine. Honestly, it's been one of the few anime worth catching up to lately, making you laugh, cry and feel excited every episode, it may seem like a plain anime at first but things goscaling up so quickly in an unpredictable way that it's so much fun and makes you truly look forward to the next episode, not knowing what will happen. Definitely worth watching!

*Hi, my reviews are bad and my English isn't good! ^_^ just a heads up! 
Honestly, I've watched a ton of anime, and that isn't saying much since many of us fans have. Banana Fish, for me, was one of those rare shows that I know for a fact will stick with me for a long time, emotionally. The only reason I brought up the amount of shows that I've watched is to say that maybe 5 or 6 have gotten me SO emotionally invested, and I don't even know why.
I knew I was in for something a bit tragic, from episode one I wasgetting these 'Zankyou no Terror' vibes, maybe since these are both from Mappa.

Zankyou no Terror had me upset for weeks, leaving me with a giant hole in my heart, Banana Fish did me even worse. I don't think I'm ever going to get over how upset I am currently, having just finished it. This is the sort of show that I almost want to make my friends watch so we can all cry together and talk about how fucking amazing it was. This show filled my soul, I was satisfied watching all 24 episodes and felt it was a solid show, yet it ripped my heart and my emotions to bits, this shit is TRAUMATIZING.


The OST was pretty good, but it didn't especially stick in my brain or anything, the ED's on the other hand, for gods sake I finish the show- and then i'm like 'oh boy the first ED was a real uhh banger maybe it will cheer me up' Yeah um, no. That was stupid of me to think and now I'm in a deadly state of severe dehydration and my salty ass tears are going to ruin my skin. 


I really liked the animation and art, it was a nice style that really brought out the characters, like Eiji looking quite bland, especially in comparison to Ash (them eyes). For the animation, it was good quality, with not much or not to much noticeable CG (cough p5a cough) which makes me happy, since there is nothing more distracting than crappy crowd CG


I know i'm not supposed to point these things out, I see some people complaining about the fact that basically everyone is completely infatuated with Ash in the show, but It never really annoyed me, knowing the place that Ash grew up and the people he was around or the line of work he was in, it (disgustingly) makes sense.


I'm not here to look through the flaws of 'Banana Fish'. I was probably to absorbed and completely obsessed with it to even be able to point things out, and I don't plan on going back to find flaws. Every good, great and amazing show has flaws, but no matter how many, if your willing to overlook them because a show is 'THAT GOOD' just means it was enjoyable and investing. For me, that is an extremely important part of any good show or anime or even story, being so emotionally invested in a show that you are willing to completely overlook it's flaws. Banana Fish really did that for me, and I regret not watching it sooner (though it may have been to painful to simulcast). 


I'd give this show a high eight or possibly even a nine, but when it comes to how much I enjoyed watching every. last. second. of this show, I'd give it a 10 out of pure favoritism. It's taken 4 years for an anime to sit next to Zankyou no terror (I will now shut up about it) They gave me similar vibes, and Banana Fish is resonating with me, I don't think I'll ever be able to make these feelings go away (why does this all of a sudden sound like a confession?)

This anime is perfect.
A young man who understands the world around him too well due to the horrors that he's seen and the torture he's endured, is faced with what he's used to. Criminal minds, criminal plans and criminal mysteries. Despite how unique he is, it's always possible to see yourself in him. When he does the wrong thing for the right reason, and doesn't explain why to anyone, choosing instead to let them hate him.
When he can't decide where his heart belongs, or whether he should live the life he wants or the one he feels he deserves. Ash, a brilliantly skilled, unpredictable misfitwho knows everything but who he is, is faced with the one thing he could never have: innocence.


To watch his character develop is like watching a leopard grow: acts on instinct, fights to survive. Ash isn't a villain, despite what he does. He just chooses to do the right thing only when he decides he wants to, which you would think is selfish, but in reality, it's what all of us are like. Ash just does it with less hesitation, choosing to do now and fix later.


Ash's relationship with Eiji Okumura is the purest form of love you'll ever see. A broken soul is conflicted with another that wants to repair it.


Don't be fooled by the playful name. 'Banana Fish' is a war zone where even you won't survive.


I could easily say this is the greatest show I have ever seen. It will be for some time. A beautiful selection of memorable and emotional music, animation that pleases the eye, voices that speak into your soul, a plot with perfect pacing and an array of characters who will connect with you however they can.


Banana Fish is a masterpiece.

damn, this was an awesome anime to say the least having watched many top rated animes i must say this one easily comes into my top 5. Just when it starts becoming dry something major happens. extremely well timed plot twists. the characters themselves were perhaps not explored as much but perhaps that is what gives this anime its flavor the fact that it mainly follows the MC and only really delves into his past... the contrast between the MC's is also very refreshing, haven't seen anything like it (maybe someone has some anime recommendations??) the mystery behind characters.
The anime does well to explore manydark themes, and to portray the corruption in society.

Story: 9
Banana Fish is a beautiful story about the adventures of a New York gangster with a dark past named, Ash Lynx, and a Japanese boy visiting America who gets caught up in it, Eiji Okumura. The story starts with 2 things first a flash back scene in the middle east where a soldier kills his comrades and then gets shot in the legs. Second largely with Ash being portrayed as a real tough gangster who is controlling the streets on behalf of the local mafia. However, this sort of story quickly takes a turn into something else, Ash Lynx ends being the little brotherof the guy who went insane in the Iraq and believes Golzine the leader of the mafia is responsible so he betrays them and steals a drug called Banana Fish. From this point on the main characters get wrapped up in a huge conspiracy involving congress men, the military, and a large criminal syndicate, and Ash Lynx with his gang and Eiji try to uncover the truth and expose Golzine. 


The anime was largely faithful to the source material and did not change all that much, although they did not keep the era the series took place in, it covered the original work well enough. In fact I personally love the atmosphere of New York and the modern interpretation of the series, instead of Vietnam they used a more current war, and they represented current american demographics a lot better. They also changed a few characters backstories to make them more current for example the former Russian agent is now a former Russian special forces member and such. Overall though they kept it faithful to the source material and it was an amazing ride.


Art: 9


The animation is smooth and clean, there were no major problems with it, the fight choreography was pretty beautiful as well and the character design, which really suits the manga version of the characters. The background art for the city was beautifully done, it seems like some of the animators have actually been to New York or at least looked at street views of the city. The weapons in the show could have been done a bit better, and the series decided not to show the aftermath of a lot of the more violent scenes but that's alright the show was aiming to be dark not edgy.


The sound: 8


The openings were absolutely amazing some of the best of 2018, both were great songs, the sound track for the fight scenes and whenever Golzine showed up were very good and livened up the show. I love how the OP songs and the main story were connected really well, and the use of lighter music and background sounds when the characters were doing more slice of life things helped give some relief in a fairly dark show.


Characters: 8


The character development between Ash and Eiji were pretty amazing, Ash starts off being really isolated and closed to the world due to past trauma however with Eiji he beings feeling more human and even able to love like a normal person. Its important to note however, if you are coming into this anime expecting a boys love show, you're going to be disappointed. Although its almost certain Ash is bisexual, Eiji and Ash do not have a romantic life together, the story is primarily focused on the main plot involving Banana Fish, and although Eiji really cares about Ash I dont think hes romantically interested, its closer to brotherly love if anything.


Enjoyment: 8


I really enjoyed this series, its one of my top 5 for this year, and its definitely one of the top 24 episode shows we have had, I believe if you enjoy animes with gangs, street fighting, interesting plot twists, strong but flawed main characters, and a dark atmosphere, then this show is for you.


Overall: 8


I give this show an 8, it was really hard deciding whether or not to give this show an 8 or 9 since it was very close, however I will give it an 8 for 2 reasons. One because although the story was great it relied way to much on Ash or Eiji being kidnapped to move the plot forward, felt like this was a Nintendo game and they princesses. Second because the ending was a little rushed and they couldn't fit in everything important, and had to rush some fights. However it is still a very strong show and definitely a top 5 of 2018.

Main character begins as a somewhat tough guy.... but endsup being a gay dude who's as dumb as brick.  The show is filled with "hostage bluffing" and the annoying gunpoint.\n

Also moves too slow.... usually a high rated series will have a lot of development and progress made over time: in this case you will see this common trope:\n
good guys try to fight fair.  bad guys break rules.  Good guys get tortured or killed.  And it is at this moment that the good guys give you the "I knew how to deal with this all along!"  To me, I interpret this as a waste of chracter's deaths and worthless torture \n

I am currently watching the 14th episode, but this series caught my attention since the very first episode. I’ve been watching some shonen anime recently and BANANA FISH came just in time to refresh my mind and open my eyes for good and solid quality anime. Sometimes you just want to experience something “human” and BANANA FISH has a really involving story filled with beautiful visuals and really really great music! found & lost and Prayer X are in my ears at least once a day for the last few weeks! By the way, those songs are so into the history! Really good choice. I’mvery proud of myself for finding BANANA FISH this year. The best finding of the year for me, which doesn’t mean that I think it’s the best series of the year or something like that, but my love at first sight with it was just too strong, and love is something you can’t really disprove in words, right? :)

It is hard to explain how surprised I was by how much I loved this anime.  A shoujo drama with overarching romance?  Eh, not normally my cup of tea.  But then I started watching Banana Fish and this is not a generic shoujo drama with an overarching romance.  This is so much more... 
The first episode of Banana Fish immediately engages you into the more action crime thriller sides of the show which immediately hooked me.  Growing up watching martial arts movies and crime shows with my father, the beginning of this show felt more action oriented than what I’dexpect out of a shoujo anime.  You immediately meet some of the most engaging and well developed characters I’ve seen in a long time who captivated you so quickly that at the end of the first episode when major traumatic drama occurs, you immediately feel that empathetic bond that normally takes a normal series multiple episodes to develop. \n
This show has so much to offer from it’s adventure crime aspects that lead you through major crime lord mobsters to an overarching mystery that keeps you on edge to a surprisingly well developed romance between the two leads.  I’m not one to truly enjoy watching romances, but the delicate care taken to developing this relationship was so beautiful that you couldn’t help but love them.  It never felt like a sexually charged attention grabbing romance, but a real and tangible relationship you just want to support. \n
There were only a few downsides I noted throughout this anime.  For one there was once or twice I noticed the CGI looking unnatural, however for every time it seemingly seemed unnatural, there were 10 more times the anime was stunning and breathtaking.  I also had issues with the lack of female characters in the show.  Now I’m not one to say that all shows must have a token female character.  I’d rather no females than a cheap characterized female that detracts from the story.  On the flip side, an anime set in modern New York City seemed odd only having one or two very background and minor female roles.  With that said, I do understand the original source manga was set in the 1980s where the lack of female characters makes more sense.  \n
Do be warned however, this show hurts so much in the end.  I became so engaged in the characters and fell in love with each of them to such a degree that I mourned them for weeks at the end of the show.  If you’re not looking for an emotion jerker, perhaps overlook this anime.  With it’s beautiful animation, wonderful characters, and one of the best intros in anime using Blue Encount’s Freedon, if you’re looking for an anime carefully crafted into a masterpiece, this one is one for sure.\n
If you have any opinions on this anime, please let me know.  I’ll be happy to hear what other people think and what criticisms or beautiful aspects you might have noticed that I missed.

Banana Fish is literally the edgy-dark new age thriller that everyone's always harping on about in the anime community. It's amazing to watch, heart wrenching, beautiful- the characters are likeable and complex AND THE OPENINGS/ENDINGS ARE ALL BOPS
It's such a shame that it fell on the wayside this season. I believe this is because people wrote it off because it featured elements of homosexual relationships and people are just... dumb? Like sure thing Chad, you didn't like Banana Fish because it was too 'edgy' but your favourite anime is Akame Ga Kill, go off.
I liked Banana Fish because it has great action direction despite notbeing an action anime, beautiful art, amazing characters, awesome OST and was a lot of fun to watch. \n
I didn't like that it was a huge tearjerker, but I suppose that's what you should expect from the get-go with themes such as rape, human experiments and prostitution. \n\n
In conclusion, Banana Fish isn't yaoi bait man-service, you're just immature.

This anime is just beautiful and it's probably one of my favorites of all time. 
The story is really refreshing since it isn't your typical cliché anime plot. The main character goes through a very harsh life and the whole story is inmerse in dark themes but the anime tries to give a message of hope at the same time.
It so worth watching, it's sad that many people don't watch it because they think it's yaoi or something like that but let me tell you IT ISN'T. There's no yaoi or shounen-ai since it isn't even explicit romance. 
And last but not least, the firstending, man I fell in love with Prayer X by King Gnu. That song is awesome.\n\n
So, if you are thinking about maybe watching Banana Fish I would suggest you give it a try.\n
Peace out.

story - 9/10
the story of banana fish is good. it's a little convoluted, and a lot to deal with at times, but all-in-all, it wouldn't be the story it is without these elements. the intricate relationships between the gangs of new york, the corruption of the american government, the abuse faced by the protagonist, these all make up the world of banana fish, and make for a very compelling story. 
we navigate this world from the perspective of two very different boys. one, ash lynx, an american boy only 17, and already a gang boss. the other, eiji okumura, a japanese tourist, 19. 
eiji travelsto the states as the assistant to a photographer doing a journalistic piece on american gangs, which introduces him to ash. despite ash's best efforts, eiji- and the other allies he makes along the way- becomes entangled in the gang conflict more than any of them could've imagined.


art - 9/10


the art style of banana fish is one of my favorite things about it. the overall look of the characters to me, is "cute" in a way. this is in huge contrast to the story itself. the settings and character designs themselves are beautiful when they standalone as well. bonus points for the characters' fashion sense. the only thing i could be nitpicky about here, is some of the between frames could get a little sloppy. 


sound - 10/10


sound often gets overlooked, but banana fish reminded me of just how important it can be to the tone of the anime. the ops and eds are wonderful in their own right, but the score itself and the way it's interwoven into the story really add another layer.


character - 10/10


these characters are very multi-dimensional. ash is a genius, a hardened gang leader, but he is also a 17 year old boy who has been through a lot of emotional turmoil. you see this peek its way out from behind his tough facade in many ways, eg. latching onto eiji. the relationship between eiji and ash was the biggest draw to this story for me. they care about each other so much, despite their wild differences, and would do anything for the other. 


enjoyment - 8/10


the parts that i enjoyed, i enjoyed greatly. however, there are some darker themes at play here with this subject matter, obviously. the abuse, the rape, the murder. these aren't what i would call enjoyable usually, and while i found most of it to be integral to the story, it could take away from the overall enjoyment.


overall - 10/10


i haven't enjoyed a new anime as much as this one in a long, long time. will be delving into the manga now

I actually decided to drop this anime when it first came out and the reason I is because of the tittle itself (I felt the tittle sound stupid "Banana Fish") & the drawing does not interests me. Now is Fall Anime 2018 season & there is not much anime that interest me so I decided to watch Summer 2018 anime that I have drop by looking at others review. When I look at the review for this anime, I decided to give it a try because this anime scores quite high. OMG! I almost missed out this masterpiece.
A very well written story with unpredictable plot.I like the fact that it makes me feel thrilling when watching it which I have not felt this way for a long time when watching anime (the more episodes I watch, the more thrilling it gets). Not to mention, every episode ended with cliffhanger. On top of that, I don't cry easily for an anime but this anime really hits me hard. I never felt sad, depressed & emotional for an anime for a long time.


Besides that, the pacing for the anime is fantastic (it's not so fast and it not slow. Something not many anime nowadays have nailed it).I also like that the story have touch heavy topics like child trafficking, rape, sex slave etc which is a topic not many story is brave enough to talk about despite this stuff is still happening in our world.


The soundtrack in this anime is amazing as well even though it might not be memorable as other anime. As for the both OP, I think is ok but the both ED is great especially ED 1. ED 1 fits perfectly for this anime & the character, Ash. ED 1 just makes me feel sad for Ash & feel likes I can hear him scream for help. As for ED 2, somehow it makes me sad & it give me chills when the song plays. The anime is not ending yet & I wish for a happy ending since Ash has been through a lot in his childhood & I want to see him happy but for some reason, the ED 2 makes me feel uneasy about the anime ending.


I am really regret that almost drop this masterpiece but I am glad that I have given this anime a chance. I should not have judge the book by it's cover.

Banana fish is actually a TV series that I enjoyed which is outside of my usual anime preferences. Flow of story with numerous twists and turns along the way that ignites the curiosity and temptation of the viewer; should be praised.
The story itself was notable with it's distribution and synchronization of characters, despite the fact that the show ended with distinguishable traits of a tragedy. That must be because of the original lay out of the manga which the series is based on; but still I oneself wish for a better ending that will in a way sort of serves justice to the characters forwhat they've been put through throughout the entire show. \n
In my opinion an animation which is based on a previous graphical novel or any other work of literature; isn't obligated to strictly follow the same script as of it's origin text; if done also limits the series's potentiality to become independent and follow a path of it's own creative making while still keeping a touch of it's predecessor.\n
Even though the series consisted of strong willed, dynamic characters, I still find myself to be quite confused when trying to grasp the true relationship between the banana fish's core characters; Ash and Eiji. It's true that friendship bonds can take many forms; but as person a who is contributing to this review after watching the show to it's completion; I'm quite sure the creators's intention solely was not to convey the deep brotherly bond that Ash and Eiji shares... So I find the lack of certitude also to be a scored negative point.\n
Apart from those few inconveniences I still find and believe Banana fish to be one of the best anime TV series made in the year 2018.       \n
[+ This is my first animelist review ;p ;p ]

Everything about "Banana Fish" is just PERFECT.
At first, I was wary of picking up "Banana Fish." Only seeing the title, I thought it was going to be one of those weird animes. In actuality, the title is a reference to the short story "A Perfect Day for Bananafish" by J.D. Salinger. Thankfully, I finally picked up this anime, after it has finished airing.
You are given two beautiful characters from the very beginning, two people who are completely different from one another. However, "opposites attract," and as the show progresses, you can see how the characters change to be more like each other. The two personalities,no matter how different, blend so perfectly. The result is heartwarming yet heartwrenching as forces try to pull the two apart.\n\n
I highly recommend "Banana Fish." Coming from a New Yorker, I love how "Banana Fish" accurately depict the City of New York. I loved spotting places that I recognized. In addition, I loved the story and characters that make up the show. Give "Banana Fish" a try, but beware of how sad it can be.

TL;DR Review
Hey, this is pretty good... The plot is great; the story follows Ash who is a gang boss who tries his hardest to protect his people and the person he loves. Ash has a really strong hitting backstory that does back up his reasoning for his hatred towards certain people. The character development is on point. Ash turns from a ruthless killer to learning how to love, while Eiji turns from a shy and quite person to a some what tough and brave hero. However, this show isn't perfect. I swear to god all the bad guys are storm troopers who can't aim forlife, and to be honest, Ash should be dead so many times but he just does die... That man is tough as hell. But on the good side, the art is beautiful and the character models are really on point. This anime is full of feels, action, and love... hehe... Well, have fun binging. \n\n
- Spacecraft555 UwU

Without a doubt my new favourite anime series - I knew it would be so from the very first episode and I was not disappointed. Never have I cried so much, felt so much for the characters or been so as completely engrossed by a television series. MAPPA has yet again created another masterpiece.
Story (10): In one word - INTENSE. This show is not for the fainthearted. Every time you think that the things cannot get any worse for the characters, something terrible happens that leaves you on the edge of your seat unable to stand the wait between episodes. There was never a lagin the story and the story was in no way predictable. It was not all sadness and doom - there were truly funny and heartwarming moments too to endear you to each of the characters before tragedy struck. It is a story I could watch again and again without becoming bored, each time finding new details and every time being rendered as emotionally scarred as the last. 


Art (9): the art style is modern compared to the manga, which is not a bad thing. It fitted the tone of the story well.


Sound (10): the voice actors are great and the the opening and I love the opening and closing songs. 


Characters (10): The characters are incredible. Being 24 episodes in length allowed for deep development of every character. There were no mundane characters - every character had their own unique personality, their own (often troubled) past and their own desires and wants. Character development in Banana Fish excels that of every television show I have watched before (anime and non-anime shows alike). 


Enjoyment (10): Every episode leaves you wanting more. I laughed. I cried. I throughly enjoyed this show.


Overall (10): At the risk of repeating myself, I give very few anime shows a 10 but this show is truly a masterpiece. When my heart finally heals from the emotional trauma, I will be watching it again.

WARNING, THIS REVIEW IS LONG O--0
Banana Fish …..wow….
Banana Fish has a lot going on,but the main meat of the story is that this gang leader named Asher meets this Foreign Japanese boy named Edgy and there are some serious things going on,but from the title of the show it's premise is Asher figuring out wtf is A Banana Fish and while doing so, he has to deal with rival gangs,mobsters, politics, his family, and Edgy all at the same time.That's only for the first half, but anyway.Things that I like: the actual story of Banana Fish played out very well, the things that I didn'tlike is the pacing.The show moves at such a quick pace that even the moments that have nothing happening still feels rushed.Around the middle of the show is where it becomes more apparent, but luckily the neck break pace of the show gets resolved really quickly.The show kinda leans into the homosexual perspective without being pandering.Sometimes it’s for comedic effect but heads up just in case you can’t handle it. And if you can’t, what are you, CHICKEN? XD Oh and um, this show can get a little triggering.






My thoughts on the extreme nature of Banana Fish

Also, I don’t know if this the right time to say this, but this show has a lot, 

And i mean a lot of mature content that people usually take or leave:rape, child prostitution,the whole nine yards. It’s one of those super gritty shows that stands out from the rest because of the taboo nature.After one scene in particular, I realized this show is not a run of the mill action, but it is a complete DRAMA. BUT what separates this from being something completely distasteful, is how these themes are handled. They are not there because lol, they are there to put how much weight and roughness the characters had and still have to deal with . At first, I thought there was a bit too much of it, but then I realized that without these terrible acts, but I realized that Banana Fish is trying to portray life and if you can’t tell, life is not as black and white as everyone thinks it is.It’s super repulsive and unimaginable at times, and I can appreciate how the show handles it. They don’t tell you the details, and they don’t go full Boku no Pico on you. If anything it’s smack dab in the middle and when these things are brought up it makes you lose humanity, but it also gives you the outlook that Asher goes through which is a good thing. OKAY moving on..



The animation was done by MAPPA yay. I love MAPPA as a studio but I always see them trying to go beyond their limits and most of the time it ends up out of their favor, and by that I mean THEIR 3D SUCKS MOST OF THE TIME BUT THEY LOOOVE TO USE IT CONSTANTLY. But actually, MAPPA decided to do something smart and make the small amount of 3d barely visible.There was never a single time I recall anything in the foreground being 3D and when you do notice out of the corner of your eye, it actually looks sorta good.They still have a looong way to go before making bearable 3D. 2D and 3D are so hard to put together anyways.The animation of the show is actually standard fare for MAPPA. They start out strong, flub up in a little in the middle and finish strong.The actual background design is really gorgeous as well. Despite the dark nature of Banana Fish, the actual coloring is super lively and bright depending on certain areas and super dark during others.The character designs are super nostalgic(probably because this is based of a manga from the 90’s) But i thought it worked well.

Also one thing that I just couldn’t ignore was how much work was put in to translating everything in English. This show takes place in America so there is English,A lot of it.From entire websites, news articles, and magazines, in full English. And it’s fine for the most part, but others are just a bit too goofy. My favorite example is “He was destroyed in a car accident” lol




Sound

The soundtrack hits the gangster feeling home,but I didn’t really care for it that much.It just all comes down to taste.Don’t get me wrong it still sounds better than trap beats and is still good.If that’s your thing knock yourself out.On the other hand, my absolute favorite parts of the soundtracks are the ones that distort the music.Purposely stalling audio, having very macabre drones, and even the emotional soundtracks got to me. I absolutely adore this track despite my distaste for hip hop but to each his own. You know what else I absolutely love??? The second opening, full of raw emotion and charming yet  awkward lyrics, and I'll admit it, it's  one of my favorite opening ever.The VA was top notch, but THIS SHOW NEEDS A DUB LIKE PRONTO.If these characters were not speaking Japanese, you would not be able to tell that this was made in Japan. Despite the great performances,I feel like the script was sort of vague on how actual american slang works, and a dub would do the job nicely. I want this dub to be the most explicit,raunchy, american dialect filled dub this side of Black Lagoon and I would give an arm to see it happen.



I’ll talk about Edgy first because he is my favorite.(I know his name is Eiji but every time someone said his name it sounded like “Edgy” which is ironic because he is the most harmless person in the show.I relate to him the most.Helpless and vulnerable but still have fun in the face of death.What I like about him is that he doesn’t talk most of the time.he does a lot in this show for a weak little Asian boy.The best thing this show did with him is make him so likable ,but at the same time put him into more dangerous and life threatening situations.And the only thing keeping hIm into this crime life is his relationship with Asher and that is something wonderful to behold.Asher himself,I had an extremely hard time liking because he had so many things about him that screamed “Mary Sue” being badass and sly , but having a very dark past.Little did I realize that the “dark past”  part comes to bite him in the butt,figuratively and literally.And he ends up going through a lot of development thanks to Edgy.Seriously they start acting like a couple and it is very adorable, these two develop so much together that they even do so when their lives are in danger, which can get random at times, but more or less these two have amazing chemistry.


The other characters in the show are hard to talk about because they pop up here and there so i’ll split it up in two categories(i told you this review would be long)


The good people

Asher and Edgy have some companions with them and i love them so much.One character gave me flashbacks to Grimmer from Monster, and the others despite having not a lot of background, still are good characters with personality that you don’t wanna see hurt. And you do see them hurt and you cry buckets for the rest of the episode. Don’t worry, it doesn’t go to Devilman Crybaby levels of character deaths, but when they hit they hit HARD.




The bad people and all in between.

There are sooo many villains in this show it’s ridiculous There are good villains, bad villains, good villains that turn bad, bad villains that turn good, but are still bad, stupid villains, people that are not villains, but just dumb and selfish, villains that don’t do anything really, and the big kahuna of them all.The main villain, Dino. This guy is an awful person and that’s what makes him a good villain.He doesn’t appear a lot, but every time he does, he just shocks you to your core.He is not the type of person to just kill you and that’s it. He gets in your mind and is a prime example of just how repulsive the world can be most times.All the others I just put them into the mold of that’s a bad guy so I hate him,Unless, they help Ash in some way or don’t completely pursue against him, they are all just the same .As in they are dirty, awful people and deserve to be in hell.




One thing I should probably mention is the ending.I just don’t know how I feel about it. I was emotionally unstable after the final episode and was rolling on the floor crying.This ending was like watching Clannad,but three times worse. Without spoiling it. It’s like you are on a interstate bridge and the road is very icy and then Episode 24 comes and the entire bridge just collapsed before  you were about to get off of it. I did not realize until those final moments how attached I got to those characters and the way the show just takes my heart and rips it out and just stomps on it in front of my eyes was just not cool but beautiful at the same time.




This show was something for sure.I would not recommend it as something someone who likes mindless action would watch, but I love it to death, I still don’t consider it a masterpiece because there are some problems here and there, but I can’t recommend it enough,there were times I had to force myself to take a break before marathoning the whole thing, I just couldn’t get enough. just don’t bring your children or parents with you.Also that ending, I could not sleep at night after it so yeah.


Overall-8


I did not realize until now, that I have been say Asher when the mc's name is actually Ash. I'm so embarrassed T__T

There was a person that was ignoring everyone, that was wandering around and deceived everything but then a person appeared in his life and made him realize how good can life be. 
Those words describe the story of Banana Fish as well as it could ever be done. We're reaching a point of ectsay while watching this gem of an anime that cannot be possibly expressed with words but only with the atmosphere that it gives you. This is an adaptation of the manga Banana Fish that was published in 1985 and while the story of the manga is based on the "80's" this faithfuladaptation takes everything it has to give and becomes even more relatable basing it in today's day and age. 


The atmosphere felt in this anime was one that tells you how while life can be an inmense burden and an indescriptible pain it could also be the most beautiful thing you could ever have. 


There are times of pain, there are times of grief, there are times of tears, there are times of despair but that is only a part of the picture because there are also times of joy, there are times of happiness, there are times of laughter, there are times that can be enjoyed more than anything in this world and only say "how good is to be alive". 


Banana Fish is an experience that gives you impotence and despair but also gives you laughs and joy, it has everything that could possibly be asked of a series with it's story and design. 


The story is based around a guy by the name Ash Claerence who at the time of the start of the anime is a gang leader and one of the most wanted criminals of his city, he grew up from being a kid to an adult subjugated by the iron hand of the boss of a criminal organization and had to deal with everything that conveys that but he didn't wasted time and was intelligent enough to be able to grow out of there and make his life his own. He meets Eiji, a person who would become his dearest one and the light at the end of his tunnel giving him a home and a family something that he never had and could tell what an experience was that. 


Eiji grows along with Ash as they have laughs but also tears, dear time that left them with a desire for more space together to live and enjoy the sensation of being alive here and now. The kindness and protectiveness that they show each other is one of the most enjoyable aspects of the entire show while seeing how their relationship grows is the backbone of the story. 


The area that Ash controls has a chinese gang whose leader is his friend Wong, Shorter and along with him leads the entire space of which his city consists. There is also the mafia, an organization that has a important role in the story and the problems presented throughout the road. 


The Music is polished enough to be enjoyable as the openings(Found & Lost, Freedom) and endings(Prayer X, Red) are relatable and well written songs that can stick around in your head for a while and have lyrics that can be able to relate with our own personal lives, the music is well adapted to the different situations that are presented throughout the story and have a great cast of pieces. 


The Art is different from the rest and has a caracteristic atmosphere that can make it even more enjoyable and unique in it's form and design while using it's art and animation to the fullest by not wasting anything and making everything as good as they can be in their own space. 


This is a spectacular and enjoyable anime that any follower of the medium should give an opportunity to enjoy it throughout the entire experience making it one of the most accomplished anime of it's year.

This anime.....WOW. 
This anime was so fresh and different and is soo overlooked by people who don't want to give it chance or think they wont like it. the characters,the music,the whole adaptation is just AMAZING.
the way music is tangled in to scenes is beautiful and gets me every time. eiji and ash have one of the most unique/compelling relationships i've ever seen. 
Character development as a whole was amazing. The art style was very unique 
i highly suggest this anime if you want something different from the usual anime being aired.
note this anime does have rough topics such as: sexual harassment,drug use, and violence.
allin all this was a 10/10 experience!\n
definitely think this deserves anime of the year!

Ah here lads... whats with the low scores floating around? Banana Fish is easily the best narrative out of any anime this year. The story is interesting, the characters are rich and the dynamic between each groups is  strong. Not to mention the art and action are very high quality. (Not to mention all the feels!!!)
I don't want to give some big explanation but if you like New York gangs/ mafia etc just watch it (It's only 24 episodes). Trust me when I say the script and animation are solid. At the end of the day that's what any of us look for inan anime really... isn't it?

I'll keep this story as short as possible and minimise spoilers best I can.
Story: 5/10
The story was what ruined the whole anime for me, it started off brilliantly and I loved the first cour. The action was incredible and it dives straight into the crime and gang life in New York. 
The story follows Ash Lynx as he investigates a drug called banana fish. Drugs, crime and action, I was hooked. Yet, as the story progressed, it strayed further and further away from this very thing which hooked me and in the latter half of the anime I was frankly bored.
The story then focusses onthe repetitive, 'I have to go save him' trope. Constantly and irritatingly, this repeated several times for about 10 episodes. It was boring and if I'm brutally honest, served as nothing to compliment the fine story built in the first half. As if forgetting everything about THE DRUG, it attempts to be a lot more philosophical and focusses on too many characters and too much drama. Eventually, banana fish loses the very 'oof' it had which hooked everyone. Following the anime, since it aired, I watched as the rating shot up but as the anime closed to an end, I also watched the rating drop, which is evidence of this flaw.


Another major flaw was the sudden changes in seriousness. The anime tackles very adult themes but at points, it loses all of this maturity with scenes attempting to be funny with changes to the art style becoming almost cartoony for comedic effect. This ruined the whole immersion and interrupted the flow of the story at points. This was particularly evident in the second half of the show and is one of the reasons I did not enjoy it as much.


Then suddenly, in the last 4 episodes, they introduce a new antagonist when we're already at the closing stages of the anime, which made little sense to me.


Art: 8/10


The art was fantastic, it was fluid, smooth and was high quality throughout the whole anime. Particularly, the fight scenes were well done and the CG wasn't even noticeable.


Sound: 10/10


Fantastic OPs, EDs were the highlight for me personally. Whenever I heard the song, the impact it had on me was second to nothing. Single-handedly turned me into a survive said the prophet fan. The OST was also brilliant and made the action more lively and the drama more emotional.


Character: 10/10


This is the highlight of the show. The amount of symbolism, extended metaphors and such used in the character development was phenomenal. Particularly in Ash Lynx. Ash is a character who is a character who suffered through his whole life, abused by those with power and left with nothing. Ash's character development throughout the whole show was fantastic but also tragic at the same time. 


The supporting cast was to an extent were excellent. Shorter who was Ash's best friend, Eiji, a Japanese tourist who comes to America along with a journalist, Max, Sing etc. There's a huge cast of character which all play roles in influencing the plot. The character interaction all carried heavy meanings and really built on the themes such as fate (Ash always being brought down and suffering), destiny (will Ash eternally suffer?), hope (will Ash devoid of love ever find love?). These were fantastic and is what redeemed the story.


Enjoyment: 7/10


Albeit a disappointing story at times, the pure action, badassery and character drama made the story enjoyable for me.


Overall: 7/10


A brilliant anime which I enjoyed to an extent but lets itself down in the second half of the show by going off on a tangent and exploring the characters too much rather than the whole crime, drugs and warfare in the first half. 


SPOILERS HERE, IF YOU HAVEN'T WATCHED, STOP READING HERE:


Ending review: 10/10


The one redeemable part of the show was the ending. It was beautiful.


Ash is stabbed as he read Eiji's letter carrying all the feelings he wants to tell Ash. This is such a critical point in the tragedy of the story.


Rather than seeking medical attention, Ash realises something, that Eiji will come looking for him and for that reason, Eiji will never be safe. So, in his final moments, Ash retreats to the library, a symbolic place of peace, tranquility but also of loneliness. Ash sacrifices himself, accepts the loneliness since it'll mean Eiji will be at peace, safe from him. Ash becomes a martyr in order to protect Eiji, as he knows he is an object of hate and one day that hate will kill whoever he is closest to.


But it's not just that, he's ridden with guilt. All of his sins and misdeeds have accumulated to an irredeemable point in Ash's eyes. Like the snow leopard who climbed Kilimanjaro, he's reached a point where he is beyond salvation and cannot climb down. So the leopard must die there, alone, on the top of a mountain. 


To conclude, it was a tragic ending but a beautiful one at that.
