Disclaimer: This review contains a few spoilers!
I'm going to split this review in categories. 
1. Story: 
Banana Fish is an anime with a fun name and a decidedly not-fun story. It's serious, dark, and gritty with little hints of humour thrown in. I didn't go into it expecting a good time (though that was mainly because I had been warned) but I didn't expect the bad times to be so bad either. Plot-wise, it's well-written and though there are some things I don't like about it (mostly the decisions characters made), I can't say that I didn't like it regardless.
(Also apparently people think this isyaoi and that's why they didn't watch it?? Well, if you're one of those people, then a big RIP because you're missing out.)


2. Art:


It's pretty sweet! Loving the colours and the brightness! To be honest, I'm really glad it got remade because the manga's art style was not something I was looking forward to.


3. Sound:


134234/10 Holy. Shit. I love the first ED (Prayer X by King Gnu)! The EDs are always well-timed with the scene and the OPs are not really my jam but still pretty awesome. At least Banana Fish gave me new music to listen to if nothing else.


4. Character:


Okay, so I started off not really giving a shit about Eiji because there wasn't really a lot to go on about him. To be honest, I was still a bit iffy towards the end about him, but I respect him and the choices he made. 


Ash, on the other hand, is strong af. I really do like him even though I majorly questioned his choice in the final episode. (Really? You're going to survive everything else and then give up when some rando stabs you? I was really hoping you would go to Japan and live happily since you seemed to have finally gotten it into your head that someone cared. But I still do understand that maybe you thought it was never going to end unless you were dead.) The little sweet moments really brought out other facets of his personality and I do love him for it.


Also, Shorter Wang deserved so much better than he got. 


5. Enjoyment:


Well, I watched this two weeks before my exams and finished it in two days and then spent the next three days rewatching some episodes just because I loved them. So yes, definitely enjoyable and a good rewatch as well.


6. Overall:


A solid show that deserves all the praise it got. Love it!

While this anime has its share of problems I just could not hate it; quite the opposite, I ended up really enjoying it.
The story is what keeps this anime together but it has some issues. It usually follows a pattern - Ash gets hurt/captured and then he is saved, or Eiji gets hurt/captured and then he is saved, sprinkled with other people getting captured and getting saved. The overarching plot, however, is quite interesting, delving into mafia wars and even nation-wide conspiracy. The anime is based on a manga released in 1985 so you can bet that it's full of pure 80's-style action.
The other strongaspect of this show are its characters. Both main characters are good in their own way seeing as they are polar opposites. They are also surrounded by fine supporting cast. I also love the character design and fashion. The characters have the 80's feel to them and it's just so good to see colorful, urban clothing in anime.


What I disliked in this anime a bit is its ending, but also the representation of gay men. Literally, every single depiction of homosexuality is twisted, save for one scene. The show compensates for that by having two main characters who are not afraid of showing their emotion and have such a great friendship while also being quite badass.


All in all, if you enjoyed the old action movies you will definitely enjoy this anime. It has it all: OP main character that has emotional trauma, evil villain who is just so evil and SO MANY GUNFIGHTS.

It’s easy to get lost in the high that Banana Fish provides. The series has all elements that get adrenalin pumping - action, love (?), drama - from war, gangs, street fights, and all that. Viewers are taken on an unbelievable roller coaster ride with loops and twists, making the stomach squeeze and churn. Inch by inch, Banana Fish brings the audience to the peak of its experience. Unfortunately, for this series, the euphoria of intoxication often follows with a crash. 
As with most eccentric names, comes a double-edged sword. It can be cast off as either ‘too weird’ or ‘perhaps intriguing’. Thanks to theclever research and literary ingenuity displayed throughout the series, the otherwise laughable title was fascinatingly and seamlessly embroidered into the literature, especially when referencing J.D. Salinger. Other great namesakes were also artfully included, such as Fitzgerald and Hemingway.  


The plot was strategically laid out. There was an illusive dealing behind the unknown “Banana Fish,” which involved the infamous Dino Papa, a mafia godfather, and the government/military. Ash Lynx, who led a gang in downtown New York and was an adolescent raised by Dino, stuck his nose into the conspiracy. Later on, the youthful boss was interviewed by Eiji Okumura, a young, ordinary and plain Japanese assistant photographer, reporting on American gangs. During that encounter, Ash and Eiji were kidnapped and plunged deeper into the gang underworld.



When it came to the art, the drawings and the style weren’t too appealing. The backgrounds and sceneries were good; all in all, above average. Excellent, however, is how one could describe the soundtrack. Especially the first OP, it was a great choice. 



For the characters, the focus will be on our two leading men - Ash Lynx and Eiji Okumura. 


In the beginning, Ash Lynx had a certain shroud of mystery and charm to him. This young man of 17 seemed to have too much brain, brawn, and spunk for his own good. He could have anything he wanted. 

After repeated spiels of “he’s a beast,” “he’s wild,” and “he can’t be tamed,” it got old. He was someone who could beat IQ tests, hack top-notch security software, AND battle professional soldiers, but didn’t even finish elementary school. It’s understood that he frequents the library and had “training” for 2 years, but this was ridiculous. He could literally do anything - a typical Gary Stu, who could not err. The only thing wrong with him was that he was unmanageable, he had a dark past, and his sole weakness was this Japanese prince(ss) who made him feel warm and fuzzy inside. 


Now for Eiji Okumura, a meek and timid 19-year-old, who was the typical Achilles heel of the perfect pretty boy. In contrast, he couldn't do anything, but make people either want to destroy him or protect him. His backstory, being a professional athlete, was interesting and had so much potential. But all he actually was was a simpleton of a boy who caused problems for Ash. 


Everyone and everything revolved around the perfection that was Ash Lynx, at the end of the day.



On the onset, the show came out booming and exciting. It had a very unique and real-to-life plot. However, during the latter half, the introductory appeal was lost and the exhilaration dissipated. From the action and thrill, to my dismay, what was left were remnants of a typical shoujo manga. To give context, I had not read anything about the series beforehand. Then I found out that I was ill-informed because Banana Fish was actually a “young woman” drama. Gone were the big boys and seriousness of drug dealing or murder, and what took over was a somewhat romance story of young men with emotional baggage/daddy (or whatever) issues who end up running the mafia. 


It’s not the series’ fault that I was unaware of its true genre, and personally, I have nothing against the feminine literary classification. The anime was still exciting, but what followed did not seem aligned or did not match the epic build up that was laid out. It's a good thing that the initial heart squeezing had made up for the second half of the anime. 

Though, I must admit that the ending was epic and quite unexpected. This did relaunch the stomach-hurling feeling and made it conclude on a badass note.

(no spoiler review) I had high expectations going into this anime, a mafia type anime, with an 8.3 on MAL.  Unfortunately, to sum this anime up, it is a badly written story with a high production value. I honestly can’t understand why many seem to be praising this as a masterpiece.
	I will start with the positives. As I said earlier the production of this anime is amazing. The art and backgrounds really capture the New York setting and really add to the feel of the show. Also, I don’t know why this stood out to me, but I absolutely loved the clothing designs. Alongwith this the OST is beautiful, sometimes the pieces they played really added to the feel the show was trying to capture, and even made some scenes. In terms of openings and endings, the first opening was stuck in my head the entire show, and the ending themes really gave the last scene of each episode an amazing feel as it often played over a scene instead of cutting into a nending animation. The fight scenes are the thing that kept me watching. Both the Arthur fight and the climax fight especially. Honestly the best episode of this anime was the last episode, It was so beautifully directed.

	That is about the extent to the praise I am going to give this series. Unfortunately, with all the great things going for this anime in its production the story and characters were absolutely garbage. 


Characters: How is it possible for a show to be given 24 episodes and not have any character development beyond surface level. I will focus on the villains first because every single villain (and there are a lot of them) are essentially the same. They either want to gain power through banana fish, rape ashes, or both. There are even some that are given literally no character motivation at all, they are just randomly introduced into the plot to be another pawn used to progress the story. Along with this, not a single villain has a backstory. No villain is given the faintest of character arc at all. Every villain exists in the plot just as a tool of the author to torture Ash and suck sympathy from the audience. The entire story is pretty much Ash getting tortured to trick the audience into feeling sympathy as unfortunately for us Ash is also very poorly developed.

	For the sake of time I will only focus on Ash, Eiji, and Shorter, the starting trio. Ash’s character is a kid who was tortured as a kid, raped several hundred of times, is good at killing things, and there is nothing else interesting about him. His only motivation is to protect Eiji. Which I guess can be an okay character motivation if Eiji’s presence in this anime was justified at all. In the end the only point of Eiji’s character is to be Ash’s motivation. Eiji is literally the least interesting character in this entire show. His presence in the show is so blatantly forced, why is he even there in the first place? He despite being one of the main characters has literally no backstory. We know that he has a sister that he mentioned once, he had a sports accident and is good at pole vaulting, which both become irrelevant after one episode, and he may or may not miss Japan. That is the extent of his character. He might as well just be Ash’s body pillow. 

	Shorter is another character who got no development and is the character who probably would have had the most interesting arc and could have had an amazing backstory. I would have loved to see more about his past and his motivations. Some interactions between him and the rest of the Chinese gang to build on their relationship and add to how important he was to him. Maybe a backstory to how he met Ash, or some more of how he got involved in the gangs in the first place. Maybe add something about him and his sister who we see twice and then forget about. 

Whenever a character dies, gets hurt, or anything happens, I feel absolutely nothing. The writing gives me absolutely zero reason to care to any extent.

On a side note, why are there literally no female characters other than maybe two or three that are relevant for like two seconds and then vanish.


Story: The story is, as I said earlier, pretty much irrelevant. It can be summed up as Eiji is caught or threatened, Ash goes to save him, Ash ends up tortured or raped, they enter a momentary time of safety, Eiji gets caught or threatened again, and this loop continued for the entire show. Nothing interesting happens. There are no plot twists, no mysteries, no suspenseful sequences, everything is just blatantly given to the viewer. This show is so mindless yet acts like it has an original plot. Nothing about this show is original and it adds nothing the genre, everything this show does has been done before and done much better, generations even before the manga. I honestly just wish that such a good production was given to a better written story and characters.

This review covers only the anime, not the manga.
I've heard some label this as shounen-ai and it's not, at all. There was one kiss and it was a transfer of information through the medium of a kiss. It wasn't a romantic kiss. As close as the two main characters became, it could be argued to be a close friendship as much as a romantic relationship. There was never anything that could definitively be construed as romantic rather than friendship. There were a lot of gay characters and a lot of implied rape but that could be part of any dark anime (Rainbow) and doesn't makeit a shounen-ai. Just getting that off my chest.


It's labeled here on MAL as shoujo and I'd disagree with that as well. Perhaps because it has some actual introspection, that makes it shoujo? I don't know. I wouldn't classify this as shoujo at all, but that's just me.


On to the meat of the review: this was a gripping anime. I marathoned through it in a couple days and I'm glad I didn't watch it live. It would have been brutal. This anime really never takes a break on the pace. It starts out fast and heavy from episode one and continues at that pace through almost every episode. 


What I liked about it:


1. I liked the fast pace. It didn't get boring for a moment.

2. Ash's character is one of the best characters I've seen in anime in a long time.

3. It was basically an "escape from the Mafia" type story with a government conspiracy thrown in.

4. The relationship between Ash and Eiji was very touching. 


What I didn't like about it:


1. At some point you'd realize that your loved ones were going to end up as targets.

2. There was a lot of rape. While it was never played out on screen, it go a bit much nonetheless.

3. The ending.



STORY:  This story had a lot of layers. There was Ash's personal story, intertwined with the mystery-thriller-government conspiracy story revolving around the Banana Fish, intertwined with the sex scandal / government cover-up, intertwined with the Mafia story(ies). In some ways, it was almost too much. I felt that Ash's story was paramount and it was treated as such and that was good. The rest seemed to ebb and flow in relation to how it related directly to Ash at the moment. it made it a little confusing at times as to what was the actual plot. It also was resolved a little too quickly with not quite the level of fallout it deserved. A twenty-second statement from "The White House" was not enough to feel like the bad guys had been sufficiently punished. 


As for Ash's personal story, it was fully developed and fully played out. We were warning from very near the beginning and over and over throughout the anime how it was going to end so it wasn't a surprise but it was disappointing, partly because I had hoped it wouldn't end that way, that all the predictions were wrong. It also didn't come about in the way I expected and it felt ... contrived and weak and pointless. It left a really bad taste in my mouth, like I'd just watched 24 episodes for nothing. 


CHARACTERS:  Ash was, by far, the most complex of all the characters and he was exceptionally complex and it was awesome. I loved his contradictions and conflicted moments. I loved his angst and bitterness. I loved how soft and gentle he became around Eiji. They did a phenomenal job on his characterization. He was consistent and endearing. I didn't feel that Eiji grew that much but I don't think he was supposed to. He did grow some. He grew less afraid and more willing to take chances, but overall, his core nature never changed, but again, he wasn't supposed to. He was the sea wall for Ash to crash into. He needed to stay the same. The supporting characters were very well done and I loved the instances of enemies to friends. Where some people felt the ending was too easily accomplished due to Ash's friends coming to the rescue in almost every instance, I feel that was an integral part of the story. Ash started off alone as an island and ended with some very deep connections that were willing to go to great lengths for him. 


ART: I really liked the art style for most of this. It was detailed and gorgeous. I wasn't a fan of some of the character art, especially when they were in profile. But it was consistent and that was good. They didn't have everyone look the same or everyone be bishie. I liked that each person looked unique and appropriate to their station and class. The city scenes were outstanding and overall it was a very pretty anime to watch.


The music and sound didn't really impact me one way or the other so I'm not going to delve into it.


Overall, this was a very good anime with a slightly disappointing ending, but still worth watching.

There were a lot of good anime in 2018, so I'm keeping my hopes high that Banana Fish won't end up as one of the shows the year is remembered by. I'm not versatile when it comes to crime dramas and can't give you a good recommendation, but trust me when I tell you: skip this one.
There's a lot to unpack here.
By definition, Banana Fish is a plot heavy crime drama. Yet if you gave me a piece of paper and a bit of time, I'd struggle to write down the events that take place in this show. And that's because it doesn't really havea plot. I swear it starts off with an investigation concerning a mysterious drug, coupled with a young man's revenge story. Fuck me if I know where it goes from there.


Banana Fish is more a bunch of loosely connected mini arcs, each with its own villain, than a coherent whole. The drug story gets lost somewhere in the mess and even the revenge story forgets what it's supposed to do. What you're left with is a rinse-repeat of the same conflicts and themes from start to finish. No one has a clear motivation and there isn't a goal to strive for. That's why it's very hard to stay engaged and care about anything that's happening to the characters.


Saying that a show is poorly paced is something critics like to overuse, but in the case of Banana Fish, it's true to a fault. The show doesn't shy away from switching between five scenes within 60 seconds. You'd think it's bad enough when each of those scenes features different characters, but it's actually worse when a same character appears in two locations within a heartbeat. It doesn't help that none of these people are recognizable or have any connections to the what's going on.


The only character worth mentioning is the lead: Ash. He is mostly an engaging persona from start to finish. Though they play the cheap bad boy card, he's still likable and easy to cheer for. The pop idol look is certainly silly, but does the trick. I have two major gripes with him. The first one being that his over competence seems a bit unbelievable when compared to the gritty nature of the show. The second one, oh God…


Banana Fish throws rape around like it's nothing. The show's counter balance for Ash's perfection is his dark past, i.e. all the abuse he goes through. Please note the present tense in that last statement. There wasn't a single villain in this show whose agenda wasn't to sexually assault him. It's like their main motive was to abuse Ash; other criminal activities would always come second. Ash was assaulted or played into being assaulted to gain some "advantage" multiple times through out the show. The consequences of these actions to a person are HORRIFYING (yes, caps lock). Yet the show treats Ash being raped the same as if he fell down and got a bruise. In no way is this properly addressed and it is mostly played for shock value. I don't know what more to say other than it is utterly disgusting.


Well, if that didn’t put you off watching the show, there's also Eji.


Usually, stories start from the point of view of an uninvolved character. Eji, like us the audience, isn't familiar with the American underground and is thus the perfect vessel for us to get to know that world. However, Eji appears only half way through episode one and his overall screen time is negligible. Instead, the show takes the rather risky approach of throwing us straight into Ashe's shoes. Ash takes up most of the screen time and we learn a lot about him through his actions and inner monologues.


Since the show doesn't use Eji to introduce us to the world, it's baffling why he exists. The romantic undertones that exist between them in the first few episodes are there only so you'd thirstily stick with the show hoping for something more. Nothing Eji does progresses the plot or helps develop any of the characters. He doesn't make any useful observations or gives new perspectives on the situation. He is one of those blank slate characters that can easily be replaced by a piece furniture. You really wouldn't loose much in the process.


The character design is rather bland. Ash is very recognisable, but everyone else is just an already-seen visualization of a common stereotype. The backgrounds aren't any better. Some ghetto locations were vivid, but most of the scenery were copy-pasted concrete buildings. The animation quality is actually pretty good - the action scenes in particular. There was a fight on a train midway through the show that held my attention with ease. Shame the stakes were never high enough to really get your blood going. As for the soundtrack, I don't recall much of it other than the horrid engrish OPs and EDs.


So there you have it. They say 2018 had a show for everybody. If you're really itching for a good old mobster tale, I hope there's something out there better that this. Also, don't get smitten by the yaoi click bait. In light of all the abuse that goes on in this show, romance is the last thing you'll be thinking about. More like vomiting this shit out and getting yourself a detox smoothie.

Probably what's the award-winning Mangaka Akimi Yoshida best know for. “Banana Fish”, at the time it was being aired sure made a loud boom in the Anime fandom, a scream that the original fans of the source material are sure to be the one who heard first. For a Manga from the years 1985-1994 to only receive an Anime adaptation after 24 years from its conclusion, which compliments perfectly the number of episodes it has (I don't know if that was an act of coincidence or made or purpose) sure was a surprise to all of us, and it was a welcomed one.
The show isoften met by a lot of homophobic criticism as it heavily deals with gay references and implies heavily on that, those are probably the people that miss the point from the story as the case with the characters that can really be substituted by anybody else and still carry on the plot in the same manner.

I feel like, for that alone, the majority of bad reviews come from those type of people that couldn't handle a simple plot device and ended up trashing the whole franchise without even (Most likely) properly finishing it.

One other side note to make, don't let the fact that this show is labeled as “Shoujo” fool you, it doesn't hold back on diving into torture, child pornography and abusive content at all. So beware.



Story (6/10):

One guy was blessed with beauty and strength. Something deeply desired by the average human being is only met with a faith worse than that of a stray dog. We're talking hoodlum of the streets and lowlife gangs, government conspiracies and threatening life and the doorstep of a brutal crime family in the unforgiving streets of New York, such is the life of Ash.

That is until he met this innocent Japanese dude that clearly was playing with fire without even realizing it.

The plot in general moves at a very considerable pace, neutrally fast natured, action-packed and also doesn't fall short on contrasting the amount of action with an overdose of homosexual encounters. As it follows the story of an abused young kid, it captured perfectly the horror of what was the hell poor Ashlan had to deal with from an extremely young age to his now 17/18 years old self.

I personally am not into the homosexuality side of the show, but it doesn't really matter in the greatest side of things, because there was still a plot to carry on down the road, and as the show tried to clear out, those are real-world problems and we just have to face them at one point or another.

The biggest problem with this show is the unbalanced choice of turnarounds. The plot relies heavily on a repetitive cat and mouse game that does really get into your nerve at a certain point. Like seriously, every single arc was just the same thing, only having different characters involved. And what was even lamer, it only revolved around this unwanted stranger (Eiji) that every part targeted him for being the supposed “weakness” of Ashlan. It really gets lame after a while.

Aside from the action and thrill filling the screen, there was a great part of the story occupied only with sadness and sorrow, grief at the corner of every backstory there is, which by the way was all concerning Ash.

I get that the story revolves mainly about him, but that's pouring too much focus the guy that a lot of other great characters are easily neglected and untouched upon.



Art (7.5/10):

This is only noticeable after a little while. It is no doubt that the series was greatly produced from a visual side. Not only was it set in an American setting, but it felt like another Hollywood adaptation with the way the camera angles were and the action scenes in particular. You could tell how American the show felt just by analyzing the cinematography that went on all camera shots and direction in general.

The weakest point here was the inconsistency of art style. It's not the fault of the source material being that old and so it had its mark of age visually speaking. The original artwork has its charm as well, but the majority of the time, there was a continuous shift between the original art style and a more modern take at times, especially considering character design and faces. It was most apparent from side shots where a character looks dated seen from the side until he or she turns him or her head directly at the camera when it's suddenly this very +2010 type of art style.

That really did nothing to hold back the series per se, however, it was worth noting how uncanny of them that was. Going either by the original art style or a new modernized one would have had the same effect, but mixing to very different and distinguishable was kind of weird.

Not to close an eye on animation, for that one was very well taken care of. Studio MAPPA invested some clearly-felt effort in this adaptation with their cleanly animated fight scenes, especially the ones involving epic martial art and bullet exchange.



Sound (8.5/10):

I'm just going to jump straight into complimenting Hirata Hiroaki, the same legend behind the voice over of Sanji from One Piece. It was impossible for me to unhear that as soon as I realized it.

Ash's performance by Uchida Yuuma, a figure not that well known in the medium, at least compared to somebody like Max's voice actor (Hirata Hiroaki), but apparently, talent isn't tied to how big your name is, and thus, I won't blame you if you thought that performance was the result of some world-class voice actor because I know I thought the same. Mr. Yuuma really carried on that role perfectly seeing how much of the emotional shifts they series goes through, from screaming of anger to crying in pain, it felt natural either way.

I can't say I got an enormous enjoyment from the collection of soundtracks used here, sure they highlighted some of the intense gunfights, but it was too intense most of the time that it was hard to even notice.

The opening and ending theme songs were of another league. I wasn't the one appreciating them from the first encounter, but they sure grow on you that you're too attached to let go when they are changed, and the same happens with the new ones just shortly after.



Character (6/10):

I was greatly disappointed when it came for characters.

Ash was clearly given most of the spotlights if not all of them, as hard and catastrophic everything was for him, you could at least beg for a wider selection of interesting characters. Yes, there were plenty of exciting faces, but the show wasted a huge opportunity to invest in them.

The only characters I think of that had the greatest character development in the show were Ash and Sing. And still, Sing lacked any interesting backstory or anything of that sort to better explain his motives, he was just there as sort of a replacement for another character that died.

There were some really brilliant faces, like Blanca, Max, Shorter, Yut-Lung and I could only keep going, too bad it went all to waste.

The show really only seem to focus on a character if it was doomed into dying the next episode, it almost became like an obvious pattern to their death sentences.

One other very weak aspect was the constant buffing of Ash's profile and the extraordinary amount of plot armor. Ash was introduced as this cold killed that didn't care much for the higher power and was just doing what he always did in order to survive. Until they kept up throwing plot devices like how incredibly of a high IQ he had. And I don't really care if he was that much smart or just another brainless hoodlum, but it was too painfully obvious to come up with that just when some secret intelligencies started investigating in his plotting. Not only that but on realistic notes, the things he survived through would put him into the status of a superhuman, nobody can carry on a fist fight, holding on to a weightful adult body that's about to fall and more, and that's just after not only taking a beating but also after being stabbed at the shoulder repeatedly. If anything, he should have bled out until he went unconscious, but I guess you just got to pull some out of the world plot devices to steer down the action I guess.

Leaving plot armor abuse aside. Some character really had a messed up sense of logic. Take Yut-Lung for example, going as far as cursing one's blood and at the same breath expresses how blood has nothing to do with anything.



Enjoyment (8/10):

Despite a lot of disqualifications, this was a hell of a trip.

Sitting back on your couch and enjoying a show isn't that hard, especially with an action-packed entry such as this one, but ranting over the little things is one part of the enjoyment, at least for me.

There was a minimal annoyance for me when it came to homosexual references, but that was easily cooped up with, as I said, it really isn't about the character as they are easily substitutable.

Concerning the relationship between Ash and Eiji, I don't really think there was anything implying that they were meant as a couple. I know I wouldn't want that, but it's not about what I want, they really were just best friends that contrasted each other, call it best buddies or bromance. Whatever suits ya.



Overall (7.2/10):

I should really raise the point of homophobic-ism, this show doesn't hold back on being somewhat of an extreme gay-ism, if you're not in good terms with that, you're better off not watching this show, as I've seen a lot of people get severely disappointed by that on different parts of the series, and end up dropping the show. But if you don't mind any of that, this would really make for an amazing ride, one that also doesn't care about your tiny fragile heart, and thus shows you the hell that Ash went through that you'd better be thankful you didn't. God be with all the people suffering from the same thing in real life. Have fun.

Banana Fish was a show I was going to overlook, mainly due to its name and plot summary. It sounded like it would be an awful show, and the only reason I gave it a chance was someone mentioning it had fighting scenes. I was blown away by the first few episodes available at the time, and faithfully watched each new episode on the day it came out each week after that. I'd think of the plot of the previous episode while waiting for the next throughout the week, and it took me a few days to get over the ending, one of which Icould think of nothing else, and got no sleep that night. I still think of it all the time, and I always look for bits of fan content or references (the one in Skull-face Bookseller Honda-san, though small, made me smile).


Breaking it down...


Story: 8/10

The story never takes a break throughout the show. It's extremely fast paced, and although you still get most of what's happening me re-watching the show made me appreciate the way the plot flowed a lot better. There was plenty of suspense, and the situation was constantly changing, as well as the setting. Many have complained about the plot getting repetitive with how often characters are kidnapped and then saved, but that didn't bother me much since so much else was going on and it made sense each time it happened. However, serious topics are discussed clearly and are a major part of the plot, so I wouldn't recommend this to younger viewers. Banana Fish did a good job showing how wrong those topics were, though. Most of the time I'd leave the episode feeling disturbed and uncomfortable, and the fact it affected me so much is part of why I like the show. Some scenes were just cringey, though, and Banana Fish could have toned it done a bit, since Ash's entire life was one long miserable one with the absolute worse happening every time. Luckily, I had been wanting to watch (or read) something with a protagonist like that, and Ash fought as much as he could given everything against him. There were also some rare moments of humor or rest.


Art: 8/10

The gangster/city theme of the show was great to look at, and the clothes and character designs were impressive. I was in awe of the art at the start of the show, but at some point the quality dropped and I began to notice the corners being cut every now and then. The last episode tried its best to bring up the quality level again, though, and unless you're looking for it near the later middle you should be okay. I liked how different Eiji looked when acting as a waiter of sorts in one episode, and how Ash seemed in another when given a suit and green earring, compared to their rough appearance while on the run and in the action. The contrast showed just how much they were going through, and the other gang leaders have a similar street appearance. Backgrounds were great, keeping in mind being in a crowded city most of the show, and even having some luxury locations (a party area and a fancy flat).


Sound: 10/10

No complaints here. The OPs and EDs were all great, and I didn't skip a single one. The openings were full of hype, and endings brought out a sorrowful feeling. All of it fit the show well, as they were written for Banana Fish. The voice actors, especially Ash's, did a great job showing all the emotions needed. Papa Dino's voice actor unfortunately died while the show was running - but his character still has all his lines (except maybe in the last episode, where he is pretty much mute, but for understandable reasons plot wise). Background music fit well with what happened.


Character: 8/10

Ash is my favourite character of all time. He was so real, and extremely impressive - even though sometimes he seemed to be too much of a Gary Stew (200 IQ, perfect fighting and gun abilities, leadership skills). There were plenty of faults, though, and he was extremely aware of them. The other characters such as Yut Lung, Eiji, Blanca, Sing and Lao all experienced character development and changed as the series went on. The villains were the weakest part of the characters and show, with many just being plain evil with no redeeming qualities, such as Foxx and Papa Dino (who at least has some interesting interactions with other antagonists, but is unforgivable).


Enjoyment: 10/10

My introductory paragraph speaks about how much I was invested in this show, and I enjoyed almost every moment watching it. Episode 20 wasn't as great for me, as I notably didn't enjoy it as much, but when re-watching it I found it to be quite good. It's not a show everyone can handle, or enjoy, but personally I found it to have me invested more than pretty much any other I've seen. I'm eager for any more content, whether an OVA or dub.


Review Overall: 8.8/10

I added up the scores and divided by 50 to get the final score's percentage.

This might be different from what I have on my anime list, as it's more of an assessed mark than the score I give on my list after finishing the show based on how I felt about it at that point.


Final note: Reading the epilogue, Garden of Light, found at the end of the manga, might help provide some closure.

Seriously, no idea how all viewers should be 17+ and this is getting positive feedback. Lots of "cheaters", I guess :D
An anime, which could have been a proper street gang story, totally ruined by a forced love story making creators believe they need nothing else. To the feminists' joy, the useless, whiny, delusional character with zero development, this time is a male.
Plot is unoriginal and built around torturing the lead character repetitively because he is all this anime has, then kidnapping the useless character bound to be his supposed love interest. Gets boring after the first attempt and unbearable after the second.  The suspensecomes from your wondering how many times people can use the same "hooks" and deliver the same lines without thinking any character, especially a smart one, would not bite the same bait 4-5 times. What is also amusing is that every time the supposed tough guy "accepts his fate" and "takes responsibility", he eventually agrees to be saved. Because if he doesn't, there will be no more episodes without the need to dig deeper and develop an actual plot.


The reason Ash Lynx (lead character) loves Eiji (main character) so much is also as badly thought of as the anime. No spoiler really. It is "because he wants nothing in exchange". Besides you changing entirely as a person, that is...Even if we accept Ash feels this way, we all know he had at least one true friend, who was not using him long before ever meeting this guy. Name is Shorter. So, what did he want? Surely, no one let us know.


The lead character is constantly contradicting his own life philosophy on whether he is way beyond any physical harm, free to use his own body as a weapon or he is just a poor suffering soul. Guess it is hard to create a full-blooded character who will suit the popular opinion and be able to get on the fanservice bandwagon.


True, there are few worthy moments such as exposing (or explaining?) US politics in the Middle East and...well, think that was it.


Art is pathetic, leaving characters looking deformed and literally faceless at times. Animation is getting so much worse as episodes progress, you start to wonder if the "star-boy" is even worth all the fuss. Ridiculous, taking into account that according to its creators, main character Ash's looks displayed later in the anime are elaborately inspired by the late River Phoenix. More likely, you can say his entire character is "inspired" by Makishima Shougo. Someone we also know pretty well from Psycho-Pass. 


If you liked Psycho-Pass, you will also love the B1 "test space", shown in the second part of the show. Very original indeed. 


All in all, the closest to this anime is Togainu no Chi, which at least did not hide under the false pretences of being something more than a character market for fan girls with an emphasis on "special" drugs, sexual crimes and extreme violence. Wonder why it was not liked and Banana Fish is, but my guess is it's because of how the anime market is lately.


I have only finished all episodes to see how bad this will be. I started with a 7 and now reached 3. That bad. I really hope this is the end and there are no further seasons. At least not with these compromised characters.

Spoliers******
I don't even know how to score this show. I absolutely loved this show until those final few moments. I'm feeling really betrayed right now. This show was so powerful and heartfelt and exciting, but then they gave us that ending and... I just can't. Ash has been through so much and the only way he finds any type of peace is through death? Like no. I'm sorry that seems so against the whole message of the series. 
So yeah episode 1-23 1/2 10
Second half of episode 24 solid like 5 stars. I liked the letter, I liked the message, but Ash should't have todie after all that.

I have complicated feelings about Banana Fish. As you can probably tell from the score, I liked it overall. I liked Ash and Eiji and most of the supporting cast. The animation and art was beautiful. The soundtrack was masterful. Almost every single one of my issues with the show stem from a single choice.
The shoddy, half-hearted, lazy modernization.
If it had made the choice to stay in the 80s, at least Banana Fish could have served as a time capsule. Its themes and story is so tied to that post-Vietnam era that they cannot be transferred to the 21st century with a coat of varnishand smartphones. If it had made the choice to completely re-edit the story to make it related to the American paranoias and fears of today, MAPPA might have had a masterwork. As it is, a lot of it just ends up a mess.


Adaptations are so afraid of changing the story they’re working with, probably because of negative fan reaction to such things. But Banana Fish is a story with so much potential, one begging for a revision or two to make it shine. MAPPA just couldn’t make themselves go there. The modernization idea itself is not a bad one; it’s simply that they put no thought into the decision whatsoever beyond “maybe we can make some of the research scenes go faster.” Because of this, Banana Fish ends up tangled up in itself, spiraling towards its tragic conclusion, stuck in the past, even as the story takes place ostensibly in some version of the present.

So, yes, I had a lot of issues with Banana Fish. For everything the modernization and adaptation made better, it made an equal number of things worse. The things it made better were tantalizing because they hinted at a Banana Fish that could have been perfect. 


I loved Banana Fish a lot too. Ash and Eiji’s relationship is wonderfully realized, making scenes much more painful than they had any right to be, thanks to the stunning design and the amazing voice acting talents of the two leads. I was invested in the story until the end. It felt like something the people working on it felt strongly about- I don’t really have a way to prove that, but it’s just to say that the life never went out of the production. It’s a show with a lot of promise- ones it never quite made good on. I recommend giving it a watch, if only for the sake of fascination. It does so many things better than a lot of shows with BL elements and it also does so many things worse.


If you like numbers

Characters: 8/10

Modernization: 3/10

Art: 9/10

Animation: 8/10

Soundtrack: 10/10

Voice Acting: 10/10

Disclaimer: these are my personal opinions, there is no attempt to make an objective critique. This product stirred some thoghts that I thought might be worth sharing.
I cannot honestly rate it positively, because it didn't give me pleasant feelings, and pleasant feelings are my main reason to keep watching anime.
But it gave me food for thought, which makes it worth of some consideration. In the end, plus and minuses counterbalance so perfectly that the vote annihilates itself rather than being mediocre.
There are several things that got on my nerves here:
- The usual gross cultual misunderstandings. I have learned to overlook them over the years, butsomehow they're still nagging me. Manga and anime authors tend to have much the same fantastical approach towards western society as most westerners have towards japanese society. It's mostly in the details (stuff like "the dairy something" on a newspaper frontpage, Ash Lynx wearing shoes and sweaters no man under 50 would ever wear on any occasion...small things really), but it makes everything feel a little "off" especially since the series has a lot of focus on the cultural clash between the protagonists.


-The homophobic feel that pervades the whole thing. I mean, every openly gay charachter is a sadistic pedo rapist.  They're all american of course, because in Japan there are no guns, no pedos and no gay people. Unless it's a deep romantic male friendship that could never go past a purely platonic bond. (But hey, I know, that's how japan sounds like these days: mysoginistic, racist, homophobic -and many other countries are experiencing similar conditions apparently. Gotta love the good sides and forgive the bad sides, I suppose)


- Japan feels much like the land of Horai described by Lafcadio Hearn. Much as I can understand the metaphore of cultural clash as a loss of innocence, rite of passage, rape of mental virginity, and much as I'm not particuarly fond of American culture, I don't believe the protagonist had to cross an ocean to find himself some violence and mafia to ravel into. They do have corruption and crime and all the bad things too. But hey, Banana Fish comes straight from the eighties, the bubble economy and al that, despite being set in the present. And probably one might want to consider that, especially when coming to the "warriors of the night" feel that pervades many parts of the narration. 


Now, I don't consider watching anime an intellectual activity. It's something I do as a form of light entertaining at breakfast when I'm still not completely awake. So why do I bother? Because this anime seems to want to be taken seriously, it wants to be so damn deep man. It keeps awkwardly fumbling and rummaging with emotional strings so much that - despite some grotesque dramatic excesses (really Ash Lynx's life is something more. You can't keep from laughing if you make a clear summary of all the terrible misfortunes the kid went through while keeping moderately sane, beautiful and so incredibly clever and oh God, he's charisma itself) - it does hit a few chords. The occasional Tsukasa Hojo-style tear is there waiting if you let your guard down. Consider this a warning if you're not into heart-breaking stuff.


I said there is some awkwardness, but I believe that's what makes it worth watching nonetheless. Because the narration seems to be much more free from charachter and plot stereotypes than in most contemporary works. Its "vintage" feel is mostly there, in this use of a still developing emotional language, not yet completely and clearly encoded.


On a note of purely personal taste, I found the soundtrack wannabe gangsta style pretty annoying. But I don't like "gangsta" aesthetics and wannabeism makes my ass itch.

I had decided to watch something from my Plan to Watch and thought it's "a perfect day for Bananafish." It's not yaoi. It's close, but not close enough.
I see that the synopsis is straight from the manga's. The hideous secret that drove Ash's older brother mad in Vietnam is in Iraq. Hmmm...
Ash Lynx is a young gang leader picked up off the streets (not adopted) by Dino Golzine, whose net worth is greater than that of everyone who wrote a review here combined. He is the reason Ash doesn't turn into ash. Now that he has ripened, Princess Tamatori steals Ryūjin's jewel and battles ensueover who will have command of the sea.

... I'm not cut out to write synopses.


Give it movement, a name, and a personal backstory, and empathy will be inspired. A lot of virtual blood was spilled. It all happened very quickly relative to how fast information can be processed by my brain.

Since its beginning in the summer, Banana Fish has been one the most followed anime of 2018. In that regard, it has captured the acclaim of popular opinion within the anime community for its emotional and thrilling story about personal bondage and greed regarding a mysterious drug. But now that it has come to a close, does it merit the praise it has received ? the short is no. The longer answer is below 
Synopsis* 
Banana Fish is takes place in the streets of New York where gangs and money control the flow of power in the country. In particular, the story focuses on AshLynx, a blonde pretty boy, that commands the drug and gang business for the kingpin of the city, Dino Golzine. Things take a turn when Ash receives a mysterious drug from a dying man;unbeknownst to Ash, the drug is a heavily guarded treasure of Golzine.  

Meanwhile, Ash becomes acquainted with two Japanese journalists Shunichi and Eiji who are covering a story on Ash himself. Conflict arises when Golzine, sensing that Ash is willing to betray him and discover the truth behind the drug, calls for the capture of both the drug and Ash by any means necessary. 


Story*


Much of the story involves the cat and mouse chase between Golzine and Ash which transpires to involve the higher powers in society putting stakes on the recovery of the drug, with each having their motives for involvement. At the same time, Ash deals with his troubled past and self hatred which led him to this chaotic present. Banana Fish alternates between the two in order to drive the motivations can be seen as a parallel problem for Ash;however, it never manages to develope each adequately by relying on cliches of crime drama. The story itself is not initially bad; however, as it progresses, it became a repetitive event of Mexican stand offs and hostages where it became apparent that there was a shortage of ideas and lack direction in developing the plot. One could predict exactly how each of these stand offs would end-ruining any chance of actual excitement for the audience. Speaking of which, the initial excitement of the Banana Fish was supposed be abut who would end up with the coveted drug. Instead, the show took a turn and concentrated more on making Ash some sort of prized genius by every antagonist available. While it is important to give importance to the protagonist, it is proper to lose focus and settle the entire problem being a character when much was already built on the initial premise. Finally, once the show did lose focus, the ending arch disappointingly decided to play it safe by cutting down the main conflict to a comfortable and easy resolution, thus it seemed as though there was a waste time for the viewer who could have drawled out an easier solution 12 episodes earlier. 


Characters*


As the show initially started, it became apparent that there would be nothing novel about the characters, and as it progressed, attempts were made to carve out unique identities but still failed. Ash is something of recently developed caricature in anime where some light skin guy with either blonde or white hair has an attitude problem and hates everything; the only twist with Ash is that he is some sort of genius as well as being being indestructible to shanks, bullets, and knives.Golzine is a typical villain that does things for his own pleasure at the expense of the others, Eiji is a mary sue that seems to see the good in Ash and loves him unconditionally despite having no credible reason to do so, and the rest are functional as can be.That is not to say they are horrible but remain uninspiring.Additionally, another weakness problem is placed in how each character developed with the plot. For Example, it can be understood that there is some romantic type of relationship between Eiji and Ash but it is done at a surface level by sprinkling some moments here and there without being convincing the audience of their chemistry. The same is done with all other characters,; the show needed to slow down and focus more how each interact with one another in genuine moments rather than being placed a brisk paces where one still has not bought in


Sound* 

Soundtrack is average with the only notable features being the second op and ed. Both songs are well made and captured some essence that Banana Fish was aiming for such Grief and Trauma. 


Animation* 

Nothing too remarkable although it is quite colorful and instantly recognizable


Enjoyment* 

Banana fish is not boring and can be enjoyed if one turns off their brain ,but it ultimately catches up with the viewer when the series goes into safe and obvious conclusions.  


Overall*

Banana Fish is a series that demonstrated great potential and could have been great if it had done things properly.The first few episodes did a good job of cutting the work out for itself ,but it never managed to develop in a satisfying manner.It is bad series that has to many surface levels executions and not enough substantive deliveries.
